items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification Title: MediaTrackSupportedConstraints.faceFraming
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#exposing-mediastreamtrack-source-automatic-face-framing-support
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/riju/faceFraming/blob/main/explainer.md
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @jan-ivar

Other information

The Face Framing API makes it possible for web apps to ask the operating system to efficiently apply the automatic face framing effect to a camera's video feed. This eliminates the costly need for manual application of the effect through machine learning frameworks such as TensorFlow.js, Mediapipe, or cloud-based solutions, which require processing each video frame individually.

This is similar to the Background Blur API
items.title: MediaTrackSupportedConstraints.faceFraming

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification Title: Web Preferences API
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://wicg.github.io/web-preferences-api/
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/web-preferences-api/blob/main/README.md

Other information

The Web Preference API aims to provide a way for sites to override the value for a given user preference (e.g. color-scheme preference) in a way that fully integrates with existing Web APIs.

Early days for the proposal but I want to reach out early and get feedback.
items.title: Web Preferences API

You should also know that this feature is a simple addition of a single flag to an existing dictionary, following an established pattern thatâ€™s also used by a few other keys of the same dictionary (selfBrowserSurface, systemAudio, surfaceSwitching). well-known patterns.

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification Title: X25519Kyber768 key encapsulation for TLS
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-tls-westerbaan-xyber768d00-02.html
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://blog.chromium.org/2023/08/protecting-chrome-traffic-with-hybrid.html
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): Dennis Jackson

Other information

This is a draft post-quantum secure key encapsulation method for TLS. Standardization is via IETF, not W3C. I believe Firefox is already rolling this out.
items.title: X25519Kyber768 key encapsulation for TLS

Other information

  • There's a PR open which has the actual changes to the Fetch spec: whatwg/fetch#1442
  • ORB has been enabled on Nightly and early beta on Firefox.
  • Chrome's intent-to-ship for ORB v0.1 and v0.2
  • Also see #81 (comment)

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification Title: Extending the autocomplete attribute to all editing host elements
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): Spec that will be edited: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/form-control-infrastructure.html#autofilling-form-controls:-the-autocomplete-attribute
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/AutocompleteContentEditable/explainer.md
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @zcorpan
  • Description: Expand the definition of the autocomplete attribute to allow UAs to provide autocomplete capabilities in editing host elements.
  • Related discussion: whatwg/html#9065
items.title: Extending the autocomplete attribute to all editing host elements
